Stop Getting Ghosted: 5 Copy-Paste PR Pitch Templates That Actually Work

You've built your audience. You've polished your profile. You've found the perfect brands to pitch. And then.. you get ghosted. The truth is, brand managers see hundreds of "Hey, collab?" DMs and emails every day. Most are deleted in seconds. The difference between getting a reply and getting ignored is your pitch. This post gives you 5 proven, copy-paste templates to fix that. This is the tool you've been searching for to answer 'how do I write a PR email?'.

Stop Pitching, Start Getting Pitched

Why Most PR Pitches Fail (And How to Fix It)

Brand managers receive 200+ collaboration requests weekly. 95% get ignored because they're generic, unprofessional, or don't provide clear value. The winning 5% follow these principles:

  • Personalization: Reference specific campaigns, products, or brand values
  • Value Proposition: Clearly explain what's in it for the brand
  • Professional Tone: Write like a business partner, not a fan
  • Clear Call-to-Action: Make it easy for them to say yes

Join Newcollab to skip the pitching process entirely.

5 "Copy-Paste" PR Pitch Templates That Work

Before you copy, remember the 3 keys: 1. Personalize (fill in the blanks!), 2. Provide Value (what's in it for them?), 3. Clear CTA (make it easy to say yes).

Template 1: The "Genuine Fan" (Great for PR Lists)

Use this when you genuinely love a brand and want to get on their PR list for gifted products.

Subject: Genuine Fan & [Your Niche] Creator - Exploring a Partnership

Hi [Contact Name],

My name is [Your Name], and I'm a [Your Niche] creator based in [Your City] ([@yourhandle]).

I've been a huge fan of [Brand Name] for a while now and particularly love [Specific Product Name]. I recently featured it in my [post/video link] simply because I was so impressed.

My audience of [Describe Audience - e.g., 'young professionals who love sustainable fashion'] trusts my authentic recommendations, and I know they'd love to see more of [Brand Name].

I'd be thrilled to be considered for your PR list for any upcoming campaigns. Here's a link to my media kit for your review: [Link to Media Kit]

Thanks for your time,

[Your Name]

Template 2: The "Specific Idea" Pitch (Best for Paid Collabs)

Use this when you have a specific, creative idea for a paid partnership.

Subject: Collaboration Idea: [Your Specific Content Idea] x [Brand Name]

Hi [Contact Name],

My name is [Your Name], and I'm a [Your Niche] creator with an engaged audience of [Describe Audience]. I saw your new [New Product/Campaign] launch and have an idea that I believe would perform really well.

I'd like to create a [Video/Reel/Post] titled "[Your Content Title]" that would [Explain the 1-sentence value prop - e.g., 'showcase the new product in a 3-step morning routine'].

My content in this format regularly achieves [Key Stat - e.g., '10k+ views' or 'a 5% engagement rate']. I'm confident this could drive significant awareness and interest for [Brand Name].

Here's my media kit with full stats: [Link to Media Kit]

Are you available for a quick 15-minute call next week to discuss this?

Best,

[Your Name]

Template 3: The "Small Influencer" Pitch (Emphasizes Engagement)

Use this to lean into your strength as a micro-influencer: high engagement and a trusted community.

Subject: [Your Niche] Micro-Influencer with High Engagement - Partnership?

Hi [Contact Name],

I'm [Your Name], a [Your Niche] micro-influencer ([@yourhandle]).

While my community is growing, it's highly engaged and trusts my recommendations. My posts average a [Your Engagement Rate]% engagement rate, and I get dozens of DMs/comments asking for advice on [Your Topic].

I believe [Brand Name]'s focus on [Brand Value - e.g., 'quality ingredients'] would be a perfect fit for my audience. I'd love to explore a partnership, starting with your PR list or a single content piece.

You can see my full stats and portfolio in my media kit here: [Link to Media Kit]

Appreciate your consideration,

[Your Name]

Template 4: The Follow-Up (Use 5-7 Days After No Reply)

Use this as a reply to your *original* email to bump it to the top of their inbox.

Subject: Re: [Your Original Subject Line]

Hi [Contact Name],

Just wanted to gently follow up on my email below. I know you're extremely busy!

My [Content Idea/Pitch] idea is still top of mind, and I'm very excited about the potential of working with [Brand Name].

Let me know if you have any questions.

Best,

[Your Name]

Template 5: The "Thank You & Next Steps" (After Getting a Package)

Use this after a successful *gifted* collab to build a relationship and open the door for a *paid* one.

Subject: Loved the [Product Name]! + Content Link

Hi [Contact Name],

Thank you so much again for sending over the [Product Name]! I genuinely loved it (especially [mention a specific feature]).

I've just posted my content featuring the product, and my audience is already reacting so positively. You can see the live post here: [Link to Post/Video]

I'm already planning my next content calendar and would love to discuss a more formal, paid partnership for [Next Month/Quarter]. I have an idea for a [New Content Idea] that I think would build on this success.

Let me know if you'd be open to chatting!

Best,

[Your Name]

"I was getting zero replies with my old emails. I used Template 2 (The Specific Idea) and Template 4 (The Follow-Up) and just landed my first-ever brand deal. This works!"

- Maya R., Lifestyle Creator

How to Personalize Each Template

Generic emails get deleted. Here's how to make each template work for you:

  • Research the Brand: Check their recent campaigns, values, and target audience
  • Find the Right Contact: Look for "Influencer Marketing Manager" or "PR Manager" on LinkedIn
  • Reference Specific Content: Mention their recent product launches or campaigns
  • Show Your Value: Include engagement rates, audience demographics, and content examples

Use Newcollab to connect with brands actively seeking creators.

Common Mistakes That Kill Your Pitch

Avoid these pitfalls that get your email deleted:

  • Generic Subject Lines: "Collab Inquiry" or "Influencer" get ignored
  • No Personalization: Mass emails to 50+ brands at once
  • Poor Grammar: Typos and informal language hurt credibility
  • No Clear Value: Failing to explain what's in it for the brand
  • Attaching Large Files: Media kits should be linked, not attached

  • No More Pitching: Brands find and contact you directly
  • Verified Brands: 1,000+ authentic brands seeking creators
  • Clear Terms: Transparent rates and expectations
  • Secure Payments: Protected transactions and fast payouts

Conclusion: You're a Business, Not Just a Creator

Using a professional email pitch shows a brand you're a serious partner, not just a hobbyist. These templates are your toolkit. Use them to open doors, build relationships, and start getting the "Yes" you deserve. And when you're ready to stop pitching altogether, Newcollab is here to bring the brands to you.

faq.question: What's the best subject line to get a reply?
faq.answer: A specific, personalized subject line is best. 'Collaboration Idea: [Your Unique Angle] x [Brand Name]' is great. Avoid generic titles like 'Collab Inquiry' or 'Influencer' which get ignored.

faq.question: Should I attach my media kit to the first email?
faq.answer: It's better to include a *link* to your media kit (hosted on Google Drive, Dropbox, or your website) rather than attaching a large file. This avoids spam filters and shows you're professional.

faq.question: How do I find the right brand contact email?
faq.answer: Search LinkedIn for '[Brand Name] Influencer Marketing Manager' or 'PR Manager'. If you can't find a person, look for a general email like 'press@brandname.com' or 'marketing@brandname.com'.

faq.question: How long should I wait before following up?
faq.answer: Wait 3-5 business days. If you still don't hear back, send a gentle follow-up (like Template 4) by replying to your original email. Don't send a new email chain.

faq.question: Which template should I use for my first brand pitch?
faq.answer: Start with Template 1 (Genuine Fan) if you truly love the brand, or Template 2 (Specific Idea) if you have a creative concept. Both show professionalism and genuine interest, which brands appreciate.
